Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant’s employees, agents, and servants—including the server who dropped the tray and the staff who were “dodging” the puddle—were acting within the course and scope of their employment or agency with Defendant, making Defendant vicariously liable for their acts and omissions under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The case does not involve restaurant servers but does directly articulate the general respondeat superior rule: once an employer–employee relationship is established, the employer is vicariously liable for torts committed by the employee within the scope of employment, without needing to control the specific acts. That general principle supports the proposition that a defendant is vicariously liable for its employees’ negligent acts (such as dropping a tray or dodging a puddle) committed in the course and scope of their employment. The factual context differs, but the legal doctrine cited is on point.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. Once employment is established, the only remaining issue is whether he was working for BMA at the time of the alleged negligent treatment, i.e., whether his treatment of the plaintiff was within the scope of his employment by BMA. This comports with traditional agency law that ‘[a]n employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.’

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because Plaintiff’s claims arise under the common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2 and G.L..proposition: Venue is proper in the Barnstable Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223A, because Defendant conducts business within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and this civil action is properly brought in this county as a court of general jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant exists under Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 223A, § 3, because Defendant regularly transacts business in Massachusetts, operates a restaurant open to the public at the Premises, and Plaintiff’s injuries arise from Defendant’s acts and omissions in Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Plaintiff was on the Premises at Defendant’s invitation and for Defendant’s benefit, and was therefore a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: The provided text is a concurrence focused on rejecting the traditional invitee/licensee/trespasser classifications and moving toward a general reasonable-care standard, not on affirmatively defining or applying the status of a ‘business invitee.’ It does not state that someone on the premises at the defendant’s invitation and for the defendant’s benefit is a business invitee owed a duty of reasonable care; instead it criticizes reliance on such classifications. Accordingly, it does not support the specific proposition about business invitee status and corresponding duty of care.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places.”

Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167\u201.proposition: The statements by Defendant’s employees demonstrate that Defendant had actual notice of the dangerous condition and failed to timely remedy it or adequately warn customers.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167\u201.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses when a premises owner may be found negligent based on actual or constructive knowledge of a foreign substance, but in this particular case the court finds the evidence insufficient and orders judgment for the defendant. There are no statements by defendant’s employees showing actual notice, nor any holding that the defendant had actual knowledge and failed to remedy or warn; instead, the case is an example where such notice was *not* established. Using this case to show that employee statements demonstrated actual notice would mischaracterize its holding.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In summary, recovery has been denied to the plaintiff in the great majority of cases where he has attempted to establish the time element by circumstantial evidence… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Defendant and its employees also had constructive notice of the dangerous condition, given that: (a) Defendant’s own employee created the hazard by dropping the tray and leaving water and ice on the floor; and (b) the hazard remained for at least approximately ten minutes, a sufficient time to correct or warn against it.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The case rejects liability precisely because there was no evidence that the defendant or its employees created the hazardous condition or had actual or constructive notice of it. The court emphasizes that there was no proof the condition was caused by someone for whom defendant was responsible and no showing that the condition existed long enough to be discovered and remedied. This directly contradicts the proposition that constructive notice was established by an employee having created the hazard and it remaining for about ten minutes.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers… The record discloses no description of the appearance of the oil which would in any way suggest that it had been on the floor for a sufficient length of time to have been discovered.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were reasonably foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s failure to exercise due care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of or remedy the known hazard.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that Kask owed a duty of reasonable care regarding storage of firearms on her premises, grounded in foreseeability of harm to a police officer from her failure to ensure proper securing of the guns. The opinion repeatedly frames the issue as whether the theft and subsequent shooting were foreseeable consequences of her failure to exercise due care with respect to maintaining the premises (i.e., gun storage) in a safe condition for foreseeable victims such as law enforcement officers. This directly supports the proposition that the plaintiff’s injuries were reasonably foreseeable consequences of the defendant’s failure to exercise due care in maintaining the premises and addressing a known hazard.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage. … [T]he theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property.”

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 166\u2.proposition: At all material times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to (a) maintain the Premises, including the hallway, in a reasonably safe condition; (b) inspect for and correct hazardous conditions within a reasonable time; and (c) warn lawful visitors, including Plaintiff, of any known or reasonably foreseeable dangers.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 166\u2.support_reasoning: The court expressly abandons the old status-based rules and holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to unreasonable risk of harm, including on the demised premises. It states that a landlord should not be liable unless he knew or should have known of the defect and had a reasonable opportunity to repair it, which inherently includes duties to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to discover and correct hazards, and, where appropriate, to warn lawful visitors such as the tenant’s guest. This directly supports the proposition that the defendant landlord owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care as described.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 166\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk… In particular, a landlord should not be liable in negligence unless he knew or reasonably should have known of the defect and had a reasonable opportunity to repair it.” (380 Mass. at 169–70).

Batchelder v. Allied Stores Corp., 393 M.raw_text: Batchelder v. Allied Stores Corp., 393 Mass. 819, 821 (1985)
Batchelder v. Allied Stores Corp., 393 M.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, through its employees, fell below the standard of care that a reasonably prudent restaurant operator would observe under like circumstances.
Batchelder v. Allied Stores Corp., 393 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the plaintiff is entitled to attorneys’ fees under the Massachusetts civil rights statute after prevailing on an Article 9 claim; it does not involve negligence, restaurant operations, or any standard of care analysis. There is no discussion of a reasonably prudent restaurant operator or a breach of such a standard. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the claimed negligence proposition.
Batchelder v. Allied Stores Corp., 393 M.relevant_excerpt: A uniformed security officer ordered Batchelder to stop soliciting and distributing his political handbills. Though Batchelder objected, he complied. This was sufficient intimidation or coercion to satisfy the statute. This interpretation is consistent with the liberal construction which should be afforded civil rights statutes and provides the State remedy for civil right violations that the Legislature sought.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in causing Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Payton v. Abbott Labs deals with Massachusetts law on negligent infliction of emotional distress, wrongful life–type issues, prenatal injuries, retroactivity, and market-share/identification problems in DES litigation. It does not address causation standards in a conventional personal injury or fall case, nor does it discuss whether a defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in causing a plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries. Therefore, this opinion does not provide authority for that specific causation proposition.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress." (386 Mass. at 545)

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable person in maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all circumstances.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that, under Massachusetts law, an owner or possessor of land owes lawful visitors a common-law duty of reasonable care, including an obligation to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition. This aligns with the proposition that a property owner or occupier must act as a reasonable person in maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all circumstances.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Restatement (Second) of Torts \u00a7 343.raw_text: Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (adopted in Thurston v. Ballou, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 737, 741 (1987))
Restatement (Second) of Torts \u00a7 343.proposition: Defendant, as owner, operator, and/or person in control of the Premises, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises, including the hallway between the kitchen and the dining room, in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn of or remedy any unreasonably dangerous conditions that it knew or reasonably should have known about.
Restatement (Second) of Torts \u00a7 343.support_reasoning: The excerpted portion of Thurston v. Ballou concerns negligence of a truck driver under federal and state safety regulations on a highway, not premises liability or duties of an owner/occupier to maintain land in a reasonably safe condition or to warn of dangerous conditions. Although Massachusetts courts elsewhere adopt Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 for premises liability, that adoption is not reflected in the quoted text, which does not discuss § 343, landowners, or conditions on premises such as a hallway. Therefore, this opinion excerpt does not itself support the specific premises-liability duty stated in the proposition.
Restatement (Second) of Torts \u00a7 343.relevant_excerpt: It is conceded that when Ballou set out from Cranston to pick up at Norwood he knew that he had no safety apparatus — for example, flares or reflective triangles — to warn oncoming traffic of an immobilized vehicle, apparatus especially important when there is a hindrance to sight such as an obstructing hill. ... Thus there was a violation which counted as some evidence of negligence, and so the judge instructed the jury.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–85 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant had actual and/or constructive notice of the dangerous wet condition on the hallway floor because: (a) The condition was created by Defendant’s own employee dropping a tray of water glasses and leaving water and ice on the floor; and (b) Defendant’s employees admitted they had been “dodging that puddle” for some time before Plaintiff’s fall, showing awareness that the condition existed and posed a danger.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s actual or constructive notice where employees created and then ignored a wet puddle on a hallway floor. Sheehan involves a customer slipping on a grape in a supermarket and addresses notice through adoption of the “mode of operation” doctrine, not through employee-created hazards or admissions about “dodging” a known puddle. The opinion does not discuss employees dropping water, recurrent puddles from employee conduct, or verbal acknowledgments of a specific dangerous condition, so it does not support the specific notice theory described in the proposition.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement.”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 562 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Even if Defendant had not created the condition, the water and ice remained on the floor for at least approximately ten minutes, during which time Defendant’s employees knew of the spill and had sufficient opportunity to either clean it up or adequately warn customers, thereby establishing constructive notice under Massachusetts law.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that, although there was no evidence the defendant created or actually knew of the ice cream, the jury could infer from the condition and location of the spill and the presence of nearby cashiers with a clear view that the substance had been there long enough that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and removed it or protected customers. This is constructive notice based on an appreciable period of time during which employees had an opportunity to act, matching the proposition’s description, even though the opinion does not specify “ten minutes” as a precise duration.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance… Some appreciable time must have elapsed also for the ice cream to have gotten into the condition it was in after the accident as described by the plaintiff… [T]he jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that it had been on the stairway long enough to have been known of and removed before the accident. The case at bar falls within the class of decisions in the first group cited in the Foley case.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, any alleged negligence of Plaintiff was less than that of Defendant and would merely operate to diminish, but not bar, recovery pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85.

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: To the extent that Defendant may assert comparative negligence, Plaintiff denies any negligence on her part.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition is a pleading-style statement that a plaintiff denies her own negligence in response to a potential comparative negligence defense. Colter v. Barber‑Greene addresses how comparative negligence and the Correia unreasonable use defense interact in products liability cases; it does not concern pleading standards or a plaintiff’s denial of negligence. The cited pages discuss the effect of plaintiff’s conduct on recovery, not the propriety of a plaintiff denying negligence in anticipation of comparative negligence arguments.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.raw_text: Ferriter v. Daniel O’Connell’s Sons, Inc., 381 Mass. 507, 513 (1980)
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and will continue to suffer physical pain, mental anguish, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life due to her injuries.
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.case_name: Ferriter v. Daniel O'Connell's Sons, Inc.
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.support_reasoning: The proposition is a boilerplate description of a plaintiff’s claimed damages (physical pain, mental anguish, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life). Ferriter addresses whether family members of an injured worker may recover for loss of consortium and for negligent infliction of emotional distress, and discusses summary judgment standards and workers’ compensation exclusivity. It does not set out or endorse this specific formulation of individual damage elements for an injured plaintiff, nor does it analyze ‘loss of enjoyment of life’ as a separate category of damages.
Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019s.relevant_excerpt: According to the complaint, the defendant's acts and the employee's injuries caused the plaintiffs to suffer physical impairment. The statement of agreed facts is silent concerning the plaintiffs' injuries. The allegation in the complaint, together with favorable inferences, suffices as a showing of substantial physical injury.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B\u20136C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages from Defendant for all injuries and losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other consequential damages, pursuant to the common law of negligence in Massachusetts and G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6C (pre‑ and post‑judgment interest).

Kitner v. CTW Transport, Inc., 53 Mass..raw_text: Kitner v. CTW Transport, Inc., 53 Mass. App. Ct. 741, 743–44 (2002)
Kitner v. CTW Transport, Inc., 53 Mass..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages from Defendant for all injuries and losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other consequential damages, pursuant to the common law of negligence in Massachusetts and G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6C (pre‑ and post‑judgment interest).
Kitner v. CTW Transport, Inc., 53 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial misrepresentation/Chapter 93A case, not a personal‑injury negligence case. It discusses c. 93A damages, lost income calculation, and proof of damages, but it does not address the basic tort principle that a negligence plaintiff may recover all proximately caused personal‑injury damages, nor does it interpret G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6C on pre‑ and post‑judgment interest. Using this case to support that broad negligence‑damages proposition would therefore be inaccurate.
Kitner v. CTW Transport, Inc., 53 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "In a c. 93A claim, the plaintiff bears the burden of proving entitlement to damages as an element of his claim. Warner-Lambert Co. v. Execuquest Corp., 427 Mass. 46, 48 (1998). While it is true that a plaintiff need not prove damages with mathematical certainty, 'damages cannot be recovered when they are remote, speculative, hypothetical, and not within the realm of reasonable certainty.' Lowrie v. Castle, 225 Mass. 37, 51 (1916)."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Plaintiff seeks an award of monetary damages in an amount to be determined at trial, together with pre‑ and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C, and costs of this action.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Rule 38 of the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure and G.L. c. 231, § 60, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
